awd_titl_txt: Interactive Methods for Data-Adaptive Multiple Testing
awd_abstract_narration:
In modern applications, very large and complex data sets are routinely collected without a specific research question in mind. Rather, the express goal is to explore the data in search of novel insights, discovering relationships and structure they may not expected to be found, then report inferences for those findings. This project provides a series of iterative algorithmic frameworks for interactive multiple testing, which blend exploratory and confirmatory analyses. The frameworks are adaptive in an unusually strong sense: at each step of the procedure, the algorithm reveals more data to the analyst who makes data-driven decisions that guide the procedure.

The starting point of this project is the PI's recent work on the AdaPT and STAR algorithms, which give flexible and powerful frameworks for controlling the FDR while exploiting side information (AdaPT) or enforcing constraints on the rejection set (STAR). Given predictor for each p-value, AdaPT lets analysts interactively estimate Bayes-optimal p-value weights from the data using any machine learning method, while provably controlling finite-sample FDR. The STAR likewise allows for generic interactive modeling while also guaranteeing that the rejection set satisfies natural structural constraints such as hierarchy principles in regression. Both methods guarantee FDR control by means of optional stopping arguments, giving near-total flexibility to the analyst to adaptively model the data. The PI will work on four projects that continue this research program by developing new interactive methods and applying AdaPT to current scientific problems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant helped me and my collaborators to make a variety of fundamental contributions to the theory and methodology of multiple testing and selective inference (my primary areas of expertise) and also to explore applications in a variety of domains including genomics, ecological abundance modeling, microbiome data analysis, and replicability analysis in social psychology.

In my view, the two most significant works funded by this grant were my paper on the adaptive p-value thresholding (AdaPT) method and my work on conditional calibration for multiple testing; both works were done in collaboration with Lihua Lei, now a member of the faculty at Stanford.

In the first work, Lihua and I developed a novel method for improving the power of a multiple testing method by allowing scientists to incorporate covariate information that may be helpful in sifting true null from non-null hypotheses. The method lets investigators blend supervised learning methods with multiple testing aims, in effect sifting a large "haystack" of hypotheses to test into smaller haystacks that are more or less enriched for non-null signals. An example that particularly inspired our research was genome-wide association analysis (GWAS) in which biologists test a large number of genetic variants for association with a given phenotype; using our method, scientists can discover from the data whether certain features of the genetic variants are associated with a higher-than-baseline rate of signals, and focus power on the most "promising" variants. For example, in Yurko et al. "A selective inference approach for false discovery rate control using multiomics covariates yields insights into disease risk," our method was applied to a search for genetic variants associated with schizophrenia. Among other findings, it was discovered that variants on genes that are expressed in the nervous system, and genes that were discovered in an independent analysis to be associated with other mental illnesses such as borderline personality disorder, are more likely to be associated with schizophrenia; and taking this information into account using the AdaPT method led to a much larger number of discoveries.

The second work on conditional calibration addressed a theoretical problem that faced the multiple testing community for a quarter century: although the Benjamini-Hochberg (BH) procedure for multiple testing is only proven to control the false discovery rate (FDR) at its advertised level under assumptions of independence or specialized positive dependence between the p-values for the different hypotheses to be tested, it is nevertheless observed in many simulations that the BH method controls FDR very close to its nominal level under much broader conditions. As a result, the method is used "off-label" in many applications. Our work showed rigorously that a slightly modified method, which behaves almost identically to the BH method in practice, can provably control FDR under a much wider range of dependence settings, and dominates the BH method under the aforementioned positive dependence conditions.

In addition to the research outlined above and the other research products detailed in my annual reports, this grant allowed me to mentor a large number of junior scholars at Berkeley and elsewhere, and also to found a new online seminar series that brought together the international selective inference research community during the COVID-19 pandemic and continues to this day. I am very grateful to the NSF and the taxpayers who fund it for allowing me and my collaborators to carry out this important and meaningful work.
